title: Warnings of unsafe balconies put Rosebery unit residents on edge
text:
Residents in yet another Sydney apartment building have been warned about possible safety issues — and the developer is the same company behind Sydney’s Opal Tower.

Inhabitants of Otto Rosebery in Sydney’s inner south were allegedly told to be careful on their balconies after an investigation discovered the strength of balustrades was “inadequate”.

The residents were understood to have been advised in a letter to prevent children from playing on the balconies and avoid leaning on them, according to a report by The New Daily.

MORE: Losses mount for sellers in high-rise havens

Tower problems causing property shift

The letter was also believed to warn residents to not allow more than three people to stand on the balconies due to safety concerns.

The four-year-old building includes 298 units and was built by Icon Co, which constructed the Opal Tower in Homebush.

Residents of the Homebush tower had to be evacuated over the Christmas period due to dangerous cracking.

Otto Rosebery residents were considering legal action against the developer, according to The New Daily revelations.

Icon Co have already been drawn into a legal standoff between Opal Tower owners and the NSW government and Sydney Olympic Park Authority — owner of the Opal Tower land.

Documents lodged to the NSW Supreme Court suggested the class action was against the government, but Icon and developer Ecove have also been pulled into the case.

An Icon spokeswoman told News Corp the company was working with relevant parties to solve the situation.

“The Otto Rosebery apartment complex has been fully certified by an independent engineer and witnessed by the Accredited Certifier as part of the occupation certification process,” the spokeswoman said.

“All parties agree the safety of residents remains the number one priority. Icon and the Owners Corporation continue to work constructively on this matter.”

It’s not known how the balcony issues came to the attention of the owners’ corporation. An inspector allegedly found aluminium posts that support the balustrades and glazing did not comply with the Australian building codes.

The safety issues are the latest in a spate of construction defects discovered in Sydney apartment buildings.

In July, new apartment owners in an Erskineville complex were prevented from moving in over fears the building was constructed on contaminated land.

Residents in Mascot Towers were forced to evacuate their homes just weeks before due to dangerous cracking and were left temporarily homeless.

A number of experts have called for an investigation into Australia’s building industry, with Labor MP for Heffron Ron Hoenig and Starr Partners CEO Douglas Driscoll both calling for a potential royal commission.

Defective buildings in NSW are covered by warranty for six years after completion but Otto Rosebery residents may be able to recoup losses from faults because the building is four years old.
description: The company behind Sydney’s Opal Tower have been pulled into another alleged safety issue as residents were warned over a scary problem in an apartment building in the city’s south.
